abstract.para: The topic covers how to create a custom module

topic.para: If the diagnosis indicates a rule is genuinely missing from the policy and there is no policy module available for the specific workload, you can generate a custom module. Many open source projects provide their own &selnx; module, which can be used to enhance the existing policy, so check for the specific workload. This workflow includes a critical review step.

step.para: Use the ausearch command to fetch all the AVCs in the time frame. Then, optionally, isolate the specific denials related to your issue with grep. Pipe the results to audit2allow. For example, to generate a module only for denials that have occurred recently, use:
This command creates two files: my-fix.te (human-readable source) and my-fix.pp (installable module).
Critically review the contents of the human-readable .te file to ensure the proposed rules are appropriate and expected.

warning.title: Security analysis of generated rules
warning.para: The audit2allow tool translates denials into allow rules mechanically. It does not understand context or intent. Only proceed with installing a module if you fully understand the rule and are certain it does not violate your security principles.

step.para: Optional. Modify and rebuild the module: If the generated rules need to be adjusted, edit the .te file. Save your changes and you can then manually recompile the module.

listitem.para: Use a text editor to modify my-fix.te.

step.para: After a review, the generated rules are deemed safe and necessary for a legitimate application function. Install the compiled module package.
